bookCover.coverDescription: An interactive book which helps to understand the basics of matter for grade 4 students.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Matter is anything that has mass and takes up space. All the living things such as birds, animals and plants, and all the non-living things such as chairs, tables, balls, air and water are matter. All these things have their own mass and take up space. Matter exists in many states. The three main states of matter are solid, liquid and gas.
Properties of Matter

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Matter is made of very small particles. These small particles are called atoms or molecules. These atoms or molecules cannot be seen with our naked eyes. Matter has weight and occupies space. The atoms or molecules of different matter are different from each other.

Different types of matter are found around us. They differ in shape, size, colour, weight, etc. Some substances are light while others are heavy. Substances like air, cotton, wool, plastic, etc. are light whereas stone, iron, brick, sand, etc. are heavy.

Different substances have different weight. The substances having less density are light and the objects having more density are heavy. Every matter occupies space. Small matter occupies small space and big matter occupies more space. Invisible matter like air also has weight and occupies space. Some substances like brick, stone, wood, etc. have their own shape. But some substances like milk, petrol, air, water, etc. do not have their own shape. They take the shape of the container in which they are kept.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

choices.question: What is matter?
answers:
Anything that occupies space and has mass.

Anything that occupies space but has no mass.

Anything that has mass but does not occupy space.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Matter exists in three different states. They are as follows:

1. Solid

Substances like stone, wood, brick, paper, etc. have definite shape and volume. The substances having a fixed shape and volume are called solids. Solids are hard and rigid. The molecules are closely packed in solids. The molecules of a solid do not move about freely. So, solids have a fixed shape and volume. The image below shows the structure of molecules in solid.
Some substances that exist in solid state are given below:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
2. Liquid

Substances like water, kerosene, milk, petrol, oil, and diesel occupy space but they do not have a fixed shape. These substances are called liquids. The substances having a fixed volume but no fixed shape are called liquids. Molecules do not pack closely in liquids. So, liquids flow from one place to another. In liquids, the intermolecular space is more than that in solids. The image below shows the structure of molecules in liquid.

Liquids do not have a fixed shape because the force of attraction between the molecules of a liquid is not so strong. The shape of a liquid changes according to the shape of the vessel in which it is kept. However, the volume of a liquid does not change no matter what type of container we keep it in. Similarly, liquids can be poured from one container to another. Some substances that exist in liquid state are given below:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
3. Gas

Air is the mixture of different gases. Nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, water vapour, etc. are found in air. These gases neither have a fixed shape nor a fixed volume. The substances which neither have a fixed volume nor a fixed shape are called gases. Examples: air, smoke, water vapour, etc. The image below shows the structure of molecules in gas.

In gases, the force of attraction between the molecules is very weak. So, the molecules in a gas are very far from each other. The molecules in gas are loosely packed. Therefore, gases move freely from one place to another. Molecules of a gas can be squeezed into a small container or spread out in a big one. Gases can be compressed inside the cylinder, balloon, football, basketball, tubes of vehicles, etc.
Is the air flowing through the flute a solid, a liquid or a gas?

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
In our everyday life there are frequent physical and chemical changes occurring around us. For example:

Melting is a change that changes ice into water.
The folding of a paper is a change that changes the shape of the paper.
Frying an egg is a change that changes an egg into an omelette.

Matter can go through changes. Some changes to matter are physical. Other changes are chemical. The two kinds of changes are very different from each other. We will look into both type of changes below.
• Physical change

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: It can be a change in the shape or appearance of the object. Since objects do not become a different substance during a physical change, it is usually easy to reverse the change. But not all physical changes are reversible. For example:

Melting of an ice is a physical change because the shape and appearance of ice are only changed but no new substance is formed. It is reversible as the water can be turned into ice by freezing the water.
Cutting an apple is a physical change as the shape of the apple is changed, but no new substance is formed. It is irreversible as cutting an apple cannot be changed into single apple.
Thus,  we can say cutting, tearing, shattering, grinding, and mixing are physical changes because they change the shape or appearance but not the nature of a material.
• Chemical change

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Anytime a new substance is made, a chemical change takes place. Usually, two or more materials are combined and a new substance is formed. If you notice bubbles being formed or a change in color, there is a good chance a chemical change has taken place, but not always.

We can determine if a chemical change has occurred by asking this question: Was the new substance formed present before? If the answer is no, then it is a chemical change. The burning of a wood is a chemical change as the wood is changed into ash and we cannot get wood from ash so chemical change is irreversible. For example:
Rusting of a metal is a chemical change because the color of the metal is changed and new substance called rust is formed.
Rotting of an apple is a chemical change as the color of the apple changes to brown and the odor of the apple also changes.
Rotting, burning, cooking, and rusting are different types of chemical changes because they produce substances that are entirely new.

questions:
1) The substance that occupies space and has weight is called *matter*. [solid / liquid / matter]

2) Matter exists in *three* states. [two / three / four]

3) Molecules are closely packed in *solid*. [solid / liquid / gas]

4) Oxygen, nitrogen and carbon dioxide are *gases*. [solids / liquids / gases]

Melting ice is a change of state. So, it is a physical change. The ice changes from solid to liquid. But it is still made of the same type of matter.

Sewing an apron is a physical change. The fabric and thread that make up the apron get a new shape, but the type of matter in each of them does not change.
